Award.AwardTitle: An ion-based pacemaker at the pollen tube tip: mechanism and functions in apical growth, guidance and cell-cell communication

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
An ion-based pacemaker at the pollen tube tip: mechanism and functions in apical growth, guidance and cell-cell communication

The project will study the role of ion and electric signals generated within the pollen tube, a highly specialized cell involved in the reproduction of flowering plants. These cells are representative of apical growing cells, a group that in addition to pollen tubes, includes fungal hyphae and developing neurons of the mammalian nervous system. Specifically these ion signals are needed to coordinate pollen tube growth and function required for fertilization. The results will not only contribute to predicting and manipulating cellular behavior leading to seed production, with potential agricultural impacts, but also to discovering new principles by which electric signals can define cell shape, guidance and communication extending beyond plant cells. This investigation will entail the development and integration of different STEM areas, including cell biology, genetics, computational methods and mathematical modeling. A data analysis pipeline and novel algorithms developed from the research will be made publicly available in R, an open-source statistical programming language, allowing analysis of complex oscillations and cell growth imaging. Educational and societal impacts include professional development of two postdoctoral researchers, undergraduate student training, and mentoring of local high school students. In addition, a number of outreach and educational activities are expected outcomes of the project, where the results and original approaches appealing to broader interests will be presented to a wide variety of audiences.

Fertilization in higher plants requires the male gametophyte (pollen tubes) to grow into the female tissues and locate available ovules, finally bursting to deliver the sperm cells. Pollen tubes are highly polarized cells and in some species have the fastest cellular growth rates known in nature. This vigorous growth is sustained by specific spatial and temporal choreographies, often involving stable oscillations, of intracellular ion concentrations focused at the tip, which in turn are generated by extracellular ion fluxes. The main hypothesis to be tested in this project poses the existence of an ion-based central pacemaker responsible for minute-range oscillations in pollen tubes, which (1) are generated by a negative feedback loop between channel activity and membrane potential, (2) coordinate macroscopic processes at the cellular level (e.g. cell polarity, apical growth, guidance), (3) are involved in cell-cell competition/cooperation between growing pollen tubes and (4) impact cell-cell communication with the female gametophyte. The first goal is to characterize oscillations in all parameters using custom-made electrophysiology tools and live imaging with genetically encoded probes (Ca2+, H+, Cl- and membrane potential). These will allow comparison between signatures of different species/ ecotypes and single and multiple mutants of gene families coding for channels and transporters in Arabidopsis. The features of the oscillations will be determined with data-analysis tools developed for the project, allowing the formulation of mathematical models. Specific predictions will then be derived from differential equation models in varying levels of detail, whereas experimental validation will be achieved by testing the predictions with mutations, pharmacology and in vivo fertilization protocols, among others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Periodic oscillations are present at all levels of biology, from ecology and circadian clocks, to neurons and molecular mechanisms. Oscillatory phenomena in the minute/hour range are, however, intriguing since they are important for cellular/organ physiology but are poorly understood in terms of mechanisms. Pollen tubes are part of the male gametophyte of flowering plants, indispensable for the fertilization of seeds, hence food production. When grown in vitro, pollen tubes display conspicuous oscillations of small inorganic ions (e.g.calcium,protons,potassium,chloride) in the period range of a few minutes. Previous work has identified these oscillations as implied in intracellular coordination and/or cell-cell communication. Intracellular coordination can simply be put as ionic oscillations working as a rowing crew coxswain, controlling the growth of pollen tubes by synchronizing cellular processes inasmuch as the coxswain optimizes the crew effort to propel an 8-shell scull. Oscillations in cell-cell communication during reproduction could otherwise be conceptualized as a rudimentary love Morse-code between the male (pollen) and female organs. Each of these hypotheses would have important implications in our understanding of molecular organization of processes and communication between cells, well beyond the context of plant reproduction. This proposal tackled two major constraints blocking the path to relevant experiments needed to test these hypotheses. On one hand the lack of proper standardized quantitative methods to acquire, analyze and model oscillations in pollen tubes. On the other hand,the lack of sufficient knowledge of repertoires and regulatory mechanisms of proteins that control the concentration of small inorganic ions inside a cell. These proteins can be channels, transporters or pumps. Along the proposal results and outputs were generated to considerably advance both these points, and bridged to a third aspect, the way males (pollen tubes) grow towards females by chemistry, a phenomenon called chemotropism.

CHUKNORRIS, or the importance of being quantitative. One of the more impacting outputs of this project was the implementation of a suite of statistical methods to deal with long temporal sequences of data baptized as “Computational Heuristics for Understanding Kymographs and aNalysis of Oscillations Relying on Regression and Improved Statistics” or CHUKNORRIS (Fig.1).These tools were designed with cell biology in mind but can be used to study oscillations at any scale, presently being applied by plant biology groups in other physiological processes, but also by neuroscientists and astrophysicists, revealing unsuspected oscillatory patterns and their underlying mechanisms (https://cmns.umd.edu/news-events/features/4439,Fig.2).

The ins and outs of ions in a cell. The repertoire of proteins known to transport ions across membranes of plant cells is growing, but not sufficient to account for the many physiological outcomes attributed to ion regulated mechanisms. By comparison, in neurons, the hallmark of such type of physiology, the major priority of Science is no longer in stamp-collecting these proteins, but to understand their properties. Neurons, like pollen tubes, use ionic oscillations to communicate, but the different scales of time (milliseconds vs. minutes) is predictive that different classes of proteins evolved in plants, even if eventually co-opted to similar functions. A striking example of this dichotomy are the ground-breaking advances made within this proposal on the family of the plant Glutamate Receptors(GLRs). Glutamate receptors are essential channels for animal nervous functions, and it was established that they are essential for chemotaxis of the swimming sperm in mosses (Fig.3; https://cmns.umd.edu/news-events/features/3926). On a different far-reaching effort, an explanation was found for the fact that the simplest flowering plant has more diversity of glutamate-receptors than our entire brain, through the discovery of a system of stores and sinks that was proposed to constitute a novel mechanism to regulate cytosolic calcium concentration, one of the finest tuned parameters in all things alive (Fig.4, https://cmns.umd.edu/news-events/features/4127). Further discoveries were produced for new proteins that transport chloride, finding links to the neurotransmitter GABA and pH, hinting at novel electrically-regulated functions in pollen tubes (Fig.5).

The luring call of the ovule to mate with pollen tubes. Pollen tubes reach the female gametophyte through chemotropism. This line of research started from a previous finding that mutations on proteins that exchange potassium against protons in the membrane of pollen tubes affect their chemotropic response to an extent that they barely produce any seed because pollen can’t find their way to ovules. This result unveiled a mechanism which is essential for food production. On preliminary experiments evidence was found that distinct oscillatory “signatures” in mutant pollen tubes may contain information about crucial aspects of cell physiology. This line will be followed through by dissecting quantitatively the nature of these oscillations when challenged with various chemotropic molecules and backgrounds by utilizing state-of-the-art methods of cell imaging, molecular genetics, biophysics and mathematical biology.

The prevalence of oscillations in different areas of science makes them attractive for STEM programs by bridging mathematics/physics with biology. This project offered training opportunities in quantitative analysis of biological functions for undergrad and high-school students.
